unnormalised: **Environmental News Snippet: Waste Management Woes in Mumbai Get a Bollywood Twist!**
normalised: **Environmental News Snippet: Waste Management Woes in Mumbai Get a Bollywood Twist!**

unnormalised: Hey there, earthlings! Things aren't looking so rosy in Mumbai when it comes to dealing with our garbage. Seems like the Deonar dumping ground is overflowing yet again, causing quite a stink for nearby residents like the Sharma family in Chembur.
normalised: Hey there, earthlings! Things aren't looking so rosy in Mumbai when it comes to dealing with our garbage. Seems like the Deonar dumping ground is overflowing yet again, causing quite a stink for nearby residents like the Sharma family in Chembur.

unnormalised: The Brihanmumbai Municipal Corporation (BMC) is scrambling to find solutions, and the IIT-Bombay is actually working with them on a new waste-to-energy project. Fingers crossed!
normalised: The B M C is scrambling to find solutions, and the I I T-Bombay is actually working with them on a new waste-to-energy project. Fingers crossed!

unnormalised: Remember that iconic Bollywood film, "Lage Raho Munna Bhai?" Well, imagine Munna and Circuit tackling Mumbai's waste problem! That's the kind of innovative thinking we need.
normalised: Remember that iconic Bollywood film, "Lage Raho Munna Bhai?" Well, imagine Munna and Circuit tackling Mumbai's waste problem! That's the kind of innovative thinking we need.

unnormalised: Reports indicate that approximately 7,500 metric tons of waste are generated daily in Mumbai. That's a lot of kachra, ya'll!
normalised: Reports indicate that approximately seven thousand five hundred metric tons of waste are generated daily in Mumbai. That's a lot of kachra, ya'll!

unnormalised: The proposed solution involves converting this waste into 25 MW of electricity – enough to power thousands of homes. The project is estimated to cost around Rs. 800 crores. Let's hope it works, otherwise Mumbai might end up drowning in its own trash! Also, let's all remember to reduce, reuse and recycle, people! Every little bit helps. Clean India, Green India!
normalised: The proposed solution involves converting this waste into twenty five megawatts of electricity – enough to power thousands of homes. The project is estimated to cost around rupees eight hundred crores. Let's hope it works, otherwise Mumbai might end up drowning in its own trash! Also, let's all remember to reduce, reuse and recycle, people! Every little bit helps. Clean India, Green India!
